heading: Content Coverage
question: What parts of a document are captured by a summary?
desc: This view shows the content coverage of the summary. We highlight in the summary the common information from the article. This helps to judge if the summary covers key information from the article.

heading: Entity Coverage (Faithfulness)
question: Which entities from a document are captured by a summary?
desc: This view shows the entity coverage of the summary. We highlight in the summary the common entities from the article. This helps to judge if the summary covers the key entities from the article. Please note that this may not be perfect because of mismatches due to having only partial entity representations in either the article or the summary. For example, if the article contains Barack Obama, the summary may contain only obama which is not counted as an exact match.

heading: Relation Coverage (Faithfulness)
question: Which relations from a document are captured by a summary?
desc: This view shows the relation coverage of the summary. We present on the left all the relations from the article, and on the right all relations from the summary. We highlight the common relations (exact subject-verb-object) in the summary. This helps to judge if the summary is faithful to the article by preserving the relations from the article.

heading: Hallucinations (Faithfulness)
question: What are the hallucinations in a summary?
desc: This view shows the hallucinations in the summary. We highlight in the summary the information not found in the article. This helps to judge if the novel words produced in the summary are a result of modifying existing information from the article (intrinsic hallucinations), or adding completely new information (extrinsic hallucinations).

heading: Position Bias Across Models
question: Which parts of a document do all summaries come from?
desc: This view shows the content agreement among multiple summaries. We project all the chosen summaries onto the article using different color gradients. The darker parts indicate that more summaries capture this part of the article giving a pseudo indication of its importance as perceived by the models.

heading: Position Bias Across Documents and Models
question: Which parts of all documents do all summaries come from?
desc: This view shows the position bias of a summarization model. For 100 randomly sampled articles, we project the summaries from the corresponding model. This helps to judge if the model is focusing on a specific location in the article to compose a summary.
